content: Consider a category enriched over the monoidal category (Set,⊔,∅)(\text{Set}, \sqcup, \varnothing)(Set,⊔,∅), that is, sets, as usual, but with the coproduct instead of the product as the monoidal operation.

An example of this structure: Let objects be real numbers, let Hom(a,b)=[a,b]={x∈R:a≤x≤b}\text{Hom}(a,b)=[a,b]=\{x\in\mathbb{R}:a\leq x \leq b\}Hom(a,b)=[a,b]={x∈R:a≤x≤b}, and let composition be [b,c]⊔[a,b]→[a,c][b,c]\sqcup [a,b] \rightarrow [a,c][b,c]⊔[a,b]→[a,c] determined by the inclusions [b,c]⊆[a,c][b,c]\subseteq [a,c][b,c]⊆[a,c] and [a,b]⊆[a,c][a,b]\subseteq [a,c][a,b]⊆[a,c].
We could also take Hom(a,b)\text{Hom}(a,b)Hom(a,b) to be an open interval, a half-open interval, an open interval intersected with the rationals,...

Usually Hom(a,b)\text{Hom}(a,b)Hom(a,b) is taken to mean the collection of ways of going from aaa to bbb, or the measure (metric space) or possibility (preorder) of going from aaa to bbb. But here it is taken to mean the collection of things you'll find on the way from aaa to bbb.
Does this semantics work with all instances of this structure? Is there a way of understanding this difference in semantics in terms of covariance and contravariance?
What happens when a≤ba \le ba≤b but c<bc < bc<b?
Oh good point, that would mess this up

Maybe you could consider enriching in the category VVV whose objects are maps of sets A→XA \to XA→X, with monoidal structure (A→X)⊗(B→Y)=(A×Y⨿X×B→X×Y)(A \to X) \otimes (B \to Y) = (A \times Y \amalg X \times B \to X \times Y)(A→X)⊗(B→Y)=(A×Y⨿X×B→X×Y).

Perhaps I am misunderstanding, but even when a ≤ b ≤ c, there seem to be some additional problems with taking Hom(a,b) to be the open intervals (a,b). For instance, Hom(a,a) should include the identity, but the open set (a,a) is empty. Also problematic (unless I am mistaken) is composing two non-empty open intervals, Hom(b,c) with Hom(a,b), seems to give an open set that is no longer an open interval.
Still a fun enrichment to consider, even if this particular example doesn't quite work.

@Jason Erbele the monoidal unit here is ∅\varnothing∅ so the identity is id:∅→Hom(c,c)\text{id}:\varnothing\rightarrow \text{Hom}(c,c)id:∅→Hom(c,c), which is uniquely defined even if Hom(c,c)\text{Hom}(c,c)Hom(c,c) is empty. Also it doesn't matter that the disjoint union fails to itself be an open interval, the composition is a map from this disjoint union to an open interval.
So I proved that in any category with this enrichment, all hom-sets must be isomorphic as sets (using the standard definition of isomorphic, not the one relative to this enrichment).

Let our composition Hom(b,c)⊔Hom(a,b)→Hom(a,c)\text{Hom}(b,c)\sqcup\text{Hom}(a,b)\rightarrow \text{Hom}(a,c)Hom(b,c)⊔Hom(a,b)→Hom(a,c) be a copairing of iabc:Hom(a,b)→Hom(a,c)i_{abc}:\text{Hom}(a,b)\rightarrow \text{Hom}(a,c)iabc​:Hom(a,b)→Hom(a,c) and jabc:Hom(b,c)→Hom(a,c)j_{abc}:\text{Hom}(b,c)\rightarrow\text{Hom}(a,c)jabc​:Hom(b,c)→Hom(a,c). Then unitality gives that iabbi_{abb}iabb​ and jaabj_{aab}jaab​ are identities; and associativity gives a whole bunch of relations between the iabci_{abc}iabc​ and the jabcj_{abc}jabc​ (you can work it out if you want). One of these relations is iacd∘iabc=iabdi_{acd} \circ i_{abc}=i_{abd}iacd​∘iabc​=iabd​. Letting c=a,d=bc=a, d=bc=a,d=b gives iaab∘iaba=iabbi_{aab}\circ i_{aba}=i_{abb}iaab​∘iaba​=iabb​ which is identity, so iabai_{aba}iaba​ has a left inverse. Applying this identity again gives iaba∘iaab=iaaai_{aba}\circ i_{aab} = i_{aaa}iaba​∘iaab​=iaaa​ which is also identity, so iabai_{aba}iaba​ has a right inverse. Thus iaba:Hom(a,b)→Hom(a,a)i_{aba}:\text{Hom}(a,b)\rightarrow\text{Hom}(a,a)iaba​:Hom(a,b)→Hom(a,a) is an isomorphism. By a dual argument, it can be shown that Hom(a,b)\text{Hom}(a,b)Hom(a,b) is isomorphic to Hom(b,b)\text{Hom}(b,b)Hom(b,b). Thus all hom-sets are isomorphic.
@Reid Barton why that enrichment?

Joshua Meyers said:

Let our composition Hom(b,c)⊔Hom(a,b)→Hom(a,c)\text{Hom}(b,c)\sqcup\text{Hom}(a,b)\rightarrow \text{Hom}(a,c)Hom(b,c)⊔Hom(a,b)→Hom(a,c) be a copairing of iabc:Hom(a,b)→Hom(a,c)i_{abc}:\text{Hom}(a,b)\rightarrow \text{Hom}(a,c)iabc​:Hom(a,b)→Hom(a,c) and jabc:Hom(b,c)→Hom(a,c)j_{abc}:\text{Hom}(b,c)\rightarrow\text{Hom}(a,c)jabc​:Hom(b,c)→Hom(a,c).

Is it strictly necessary that this be the definition? This seems like a canonical choice, but there could be others, right?
In any case, that's a really cool result!

It is necessary! Precompose the composition with the inclusions Hom(a,b)⊆Hom(a,c)\text{Hom}(a,b)\subseteq \text{Hom}(a,c)Hom(a,b)⊆Hom(a,c) and Hom(b,c)⊆Hom(a,c)\text{Hom}(b,c)\subseteq \text{Hom}(a,c)Hom(b,c)⊆Hom(a,c) to get iabci_{abc}iabc​ and jabcj_{abc}jabc​. Then the universal property of coproduct says that iabci_{abc}iabc​ and jabcj_{abc}jabc​ uniquely determine the composition.
Aha I see now, I was just being slow. :sweat_smile:
